Kalayarkoil (Arulmigu Sornakaleeswarar Temple)
Arulmigu Sornakaleeswarar Temple, commonly referred to as Swarna Kaleeswarar Temple or Kalayarkoil (Tamil: காளையார் கோவில்), is a Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Shiva in Sivaganga district, Tamil Nadu, India. It is one of the Paadal Petra Sthalams—shrines praised in the Tevaram by the Nayanmar saints. The temple is noted for its architecture, history of inscriptions and connection with the Marudu Pandiyar brothers who resisted British colonialism.
Etymology
The name Kalayarkoil is derived from Kaleeswarar (a form of Shiva); over time “Kaleeswaran” came to be colloquially pronounced “Kalaiyar / Kalayar”.

Historical Record and Inscriptions
The temple’s inscriptions show contributions from various Pandya kings. For example, an inscription during King Sundara Pandya’s 12th year (AR 575 of 1902, SII, VIII‑166) mentions an endowment of Thirumanjanam (sacred bath) and Naivedyam, also land grant of 4 ma with tax exemptions.

+2
Another inscription under Pandya King Kulasekara Pandya (14th year) records land grants to temple dancers (with titles such as Thalaikoli) and identifies lands purchased from individuals, conversion of tanks into usable land, tax exemptions, etc.
Wandering Heritager
+1
Pandya King Veera Pandya also made endowments to sub‑shrines, and donations of grains and money are recorded in inscriptions.
Veludharan
In more recent history, the Marudu Pandiyar brothers (late 18th century) made substantial contributions: building the front mandapa (hall), the temple chariot, donating 40 villages, and gold jewellery etc.

Role in Anti‑Colonial Resistance
The Marudu brothers (Periya Marudu and Chinna Marudu), rulers of Sivaganga, played a central role in resistance against British colonial forces. The temple was involved in those events.

In 1772, forces under Colonel Joseph Smith and Captain Bonjour attacked Kalaiyar Kovil; Rajah Muthu Vaduganatha Thevar, with the Marudu brothers, defended it but many soldiers including the king fell, and the temple was plundered.

Important festivals observed include Vaikasi Visakam, Thai Poosam, Aadi Pooram (dedicated to Swarnavalli Amman) among others.
